statement.text: End-to-side anastomosis is the most commonly used vascular anastomosis technique for bypass surgery, joining the end of a graft or vessel to the side of another vessel. This technique preserves flow in the native vessel while providing additional inflow or outflow. The anastomosis requires an arteriotomy matched to the graft diameter, precise heel-and-toe suturing, and attention to geometry to prevent kinking or flow disturbance.
statement.formal: End-to-Side Anastomosis: Arteriotomy (length = 1.5x graft diameter) → Bevel graft end (45-60°) → Place heel suture first → Run continuous suture around → Complete at toe | Geometry: 30-45° angle from vessel, avoid acute angles | Critical: Match diameters, prevent kinking, intima-to-intima contact

explanation.intuition: An end-to-side anastomosis is like connecting a garden hose to the side of a main water pipe - you cut a hole in the pipe and attach the hose at an angle. This lets water continue flowing through the main pipe while also going into the hose. The angle matters because if you connect it too sharply, flow gets disrupted and turbulent.
explanation.key_insight: The geometry of the end-to-side anastomosis determines its long-term patency. The graft should come off at a 30-45° angle - too acute causes turbulence at the heel, too obtuse causes turbulence at the toe. The arteriotomy length should be about 1.5 times the graft diameter to prevent stenosis, and the graft should be beveled to match this length.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: (1) Clamp vessel proximal and distal to intended anastomosis site; (2) Make longitudinal arteriotomy (length = 1.5x graft diameter); (3) May extend with Potts scissors; (4) Bevel graft end to 45-60° angle; (5) Place first suture at heel with inside-out/outside-in mattress; (6) Run suture along one side to toe; (7) Place second arm of suture; (8) Run along other side to meet first at toe; (9) Before completing, flush graft and back-bleed; (10) Tie at toe; (11) Release clamps (distal first, then proximal for outflow; proximal first for inflow); (12) Check hemostasis and anastomosis geometry. Alternative: Parachute technique for deep locations - place all sutures first, then slide graft down.
common_misconceptions: Bigger arteriotomy is better - too long causes stenosis, too short causes high velocity and turbulence
The angle doesn't matter - acute angles cause flow separation and intimal hyperplasia
You should always come off at 90° - 30-45° angle provides optimal hemodynamics
Interrupted sutures are always better - running technique is faster and usually equivalent

definitions_glossary.arteriotomy: Incision into an artery for anastomosis or access
definitions_glossary.heel: The proximal end of an end-to-side anastomosis (closest to inflow)
definitions_glossary.toe: The distal end of an end-to-side anastomosis (farthest from inflow)
definitions_glossary.bevel: Angled cut on graft end to match arteriotomy geometry
definitions_glossary.flow_separation: Region of stagnant flow at anastomosis that promotes thrombosis

indications: Any bypass where native vessel flow must be preserved
contraindications: Severely calcified vessel (difficult to create arteriotomy)
Very small target vessel where arteriotomy would compromise lumen
Heavily diseased target vessel requiring endarterectomy first

arteriotomy_creation.clamp_placement: Proximal and distal, allowing adequate working space
arteriotomy_creation.length: 1.5 times graft diameter (longer for vein grafts)
arteriotomy_creation.instruments: 11-blade to start, Potts scissors to extend
arteriotomy_creation.considerations: Avoid plaque if present, place in healthy segment

graft_preparation.orientation: Match curvature to lie naturally against artery
graft_preparation.vein_graft: Check for twists, orient valves to allow flow

steps: Run one arm along lateral wall to toe
Run other arm along medial wall
Leave loop for flushing before completing

geometry_optimization.routing: Graft should follow natural tissue planes
geometry_optimization.kinking_prevention: Gentle curves, no acute bends, adequate length

complications.prevention: Proper geometry, adequate arteriotomy length, precise technique
complications.management: Angioplasty, patch revision, or redo anastomosis

complications.prevention: Proper graft length, appropriate angle, tunnel placement

complications.management: Thrombectomy, revise anastomosis if technical issue

definition.@value: Surgical technique of joining the end of a graft or vessel to the side of another vessel, preserving native vessel flow

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Anastomotic Techniques.
Longest patency review of vascular anastomosis techniques. J Vasc Surg.

learning_objectives: Describe the principles of end-to-side vascular anastomosis
Perform an end-to-side anastomosis with proper geometry
Understand the hemodynamic considerations of anastomotic angle
clinical_pearls: Arteriotomy length = 1.5x graft diameter - this prevents stenosis
Always start at the heel - if you run into trouble, it's easier to fix at the toe
Check for kinking before completing - a kinked graft will fail immediately
For vein grafts, make sure the valves are oriented correctly and there's no twist

medicalCode.description: Bypass femoral artery to popliteal artery with autologous venous tissue
